item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-12-08
item.description:
Today I did a portion of a coffee table as a negative space exercise (from DotRSotB). The lighting wasn't great, but it still worked out okay. I should probably do this more with better lit subjects. After drawing the negative space, I went ahead and started shading values for fun.

I think the biggest problem is the weirdness in proportion and angle with the two back legs.

Materials Used: cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil

item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-11-30
item.description:
A few more gesture drawings, still focused on economy of line while getting an accurate representation of the subject's action and gesture. Also, for fun, I did an observational drawing of a face from a reference photo.

Materials Used: cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil

item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-11-28
item.description:
Today I drew... circles and beans? The beans are supposedly useful practice, because drawing the torso can be roughly simplified to one of these beans. I got this exercise from Glen Vlippu's drawing book. Also, if you haven't seen Glen Vilppu draw, maybe check him out. It's mesmerizing. He's like the Bob Ross of drawing.

Materials Used: cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil

item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-11-24
item.description:
More gesture drawings, after watching a few YouTube videos of people with much more skill than me doing their own gesture drawings. In retrospect, I think the first batch was something of a mess. Just messy lines everywhere. Which is kind of how I still read the instruction from my book, but others are saying to try and make continuous, smooth, long, flowing lines that capture the gesture of the form. That seems more like it will develop skill long-term, so I'm focusing a bit more on economy of line with this batch.

Materials Used: cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil

item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-11-20
item.description:
I'm grouping a few days together here, but my second minor drawing expedition, in addition to the contour drawings, was doing some gesture drawings. I found some websites online that automatically cycle through timed poses of models, which is really helpful! My favorite so far is line-of-action's.

Still using cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil.

item.title: Drawing Practice 2019-11-16
item.description:
I've been dreaming of being able to draw well for at least twenty years. I've successfully delayed putting ANY effort towards this dream for... hmm, let's see, at least twenty years! There's something about being able to capture the life and vibrancy of the human form on a simple sheet of paper that I find really beautiful. While on sabbatical this year, I decided I should actually give it a shot. On my first day drawing, I did a few contour exercises, as instructed by The Natural Way to Draw, by Kimon Nicolaides.

The way you do these contour drawings is to look at your paper, put your pencil on a point, then look away from the paper, and at what you're drawing, until you pick the pencil up to start a new contour. So you're never actually looking at the paper when the pencil is moving. The book tells me to imagine as hard as I can that the pencil is literally touching and tracing the contours of the subject itself. It's hard!

Materials Used: cheap sketchbook and #2 pencil
